intro: Psychotria hexandra f. forbesii, commonly known as the "Bushman's poison" or "Coca of the forest," is a flowering plant native to tropical regions of Africa. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its small, elliptical leaves and clusters of small, white to greenish-white flowers. The plant contains various alkaloids, including cocaine and other psychoactive compounds, which have been historically used by indigenous peoples for medicinal and ritual purposes. It thrives in humid, shaded environments and is often found in dense tropical forests. Due to its chemical composition, it has attracted scientific interest for both its potential medicinal properties and its role in traditional practices.
